Topic: Azumaya algebras

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 20:53):

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 20:56):

So, there are two apparently equivalent definitions of an [[Azumaya algebra]] AAA over a commutative ring RRR:

  • an algebra AAA for which there's an algebra BBB such that B⊗AB \otimes AB⊗A is [[Morita equivalent]] to RRR.

  • an algebra AAA that's a [[separable algebra]] whose center is RRR.

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 20:57):

The first definition is conceptually nice because there's a monoidal bicategory of

  • algebras over RRR
  • bimodules
  • bimodule homomorphisms

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 20:57):

where the monoidal structure comes from tensor product of algebras over RRR.

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 21:00):

Then the first definition is saying the object AAA is Azumaya iff it's invertible: there's a BBB such that B⊗A≃IB \otimes A \simeq IB⊗A≃I in this monoidal bicategory.

(I believe this implies A⊗B≃IA \otimes B \simeq IA⊗B≃I, but I don't see why. I'd better check: if it doesn't, then there's a paper out there giving a bad definition of Azumaya algebra!)

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 21:02):

The second definition sounds less categorical, but actually a separable algebra is one where the multiplication A⊗RA→AA \otimes_R A \to AA⊗R​A→A has a section (that is, a right inverse) in the category of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules.

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 21:04):

And this is very nice! First, it makes sense very generally: for any monoid object AAA in any monoidal category, we can say it's separable if its multiplication has right inverse in the category of A,AA,AA,A-biactions. Second, this right inverse makes AAA into a [[Frobenius monoid]].

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 21:05):

Proving this is easy and fun with string diagrams.

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 21:06):

So, my question is whether there's an elegant proof that the two definitions of Azumaya algebra agree... a proof that might be generalized to other contexts.

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 22:35):

Say AAA is the algebra of n×nn \times nn×n matrices with entries in RRR. Let eij∈Ae_{i j} \in Aeij​∈A be the elementary matrices. Then here's a map A↦A⊗RAA \mapsto A \otimes_R A A↦A⊗R​A that's a right inverse for multiplication:

eij↦1n∑k=1neik⊗ekj e_{ij} \mapsto \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^n e_{ik} \otimes e_{kj}eij​↦n1​∑k=1n​eik​⊗ekj​

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 22:35):

But notice, this only works if we can divide by nnn in RRR.

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 22:36):

So it turns out, for example, that the algebra of n×nn \times nn×n matrices with entries in a field of characteristic ppp is separable iff nnn is not divisible by ppp.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (May 26 2023 at 22:37):

Thanks, nice example!

John Baez (May 26 2023 at 22:39):

Similarly the group algebra k[G]k[G]k[G] of a finite group is separable iff the order of the group GGG is not divisible by the characteristic of the field kkk. Nasty things happen when the order of the group is divisible by the characteristic of the field... and that's why nobody knows all the irreducible representations of symmetric groups SnS_nSn​ over finite fields.

This is a shocking hole in our knowledge, and if climate change weren't a problem and I was king of the Earth I would declare it an emergency. :upside_down:

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 00:36):

So, back to my original question. For any RRR-algebra AAA, the following are equivalent:

1) there's an algebra BBB such that B⊗RAB \otimes_R AB⊗R​A is Morita equivalent to RRR

2) AAA is separable and its center is RRR?

But what's the slickest proof? Can we find a proof that uses just string diagrams or other category-theoretic machinery?

To do this we should try to work in the symmetric monoidal bicategory Mod(R)\mathbf{Mod}(R)Mod(R) of

  • RRR-algebras,
  • bimodules between such algebras, and
  • bimodule homomorphisms

as much as possible, since that may let us generalize to other (sufficiently nice) symmetric monoidal bicategories.

Condition 1) is clearly phrased in terms of this monoidal bicategory Mod(R)\mathbf{Mod}(R)Mod(R): it's just saying that our object AAA has an object BBB that's a "tensor inverse" of AAA.

For condition 2), "separability" is nicely phrased in terms of this bicategory: it's saying that multiplication A⊗RA→AA \otimes_R A \to AA⊗R​A→A, viewed as homomorphism of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules, has a right inverse! But what about this business of the center of AAA being RRR? That sounds hard to express abstractly.

But then I remembered: any separable algebra is a Frobenius algebra! And for any Frobenius algebra AAA (over a field RRR, at least) there's a god-given way to project it down to its center! We comultiply A→A⊗RAA \to A \otimes_R AA→A⊗R​A, then use the symmetry to "switch" A⊗RA→A⊗RA A \otimes_R A \to A \otimes_R AA⊗R​A→A⊗R​A, and then multiply A⊗RA→AA \otimes_R A \to AA⊗R​A→A. This gives an idempotent p:A→Ap: A \to Ap:A→A that projects AAA down to its center. I showed why this works on page 84 here.

So, I think there's a nice way to say the center of AAA is just RRR when AAA is separable. We say this map p:A→Ap: A \to Ap:A→A equals the counit ϵ:A→R\epsilon: A \to Rϵ:A→R followed by the unit ι:R→A\iota : R \to Aι:R→A.

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 00:39):

So now conditions 1) and 2) are things I can say in any symmetric monoidal bicategory, and I can try to show they're equivalent... or at least show one implication, perhaps.

I have looked at it, but I looked at it again 10 minutes ago (before reading you comment!) and noticed that it says this:

Starting from the seventies, several categorical approaches to Azumaya algebras and the Brauer group have been proposed (see the bibliography in [23] for some references). Almost all these approaches deal with Azumaya monoids in a monoidal category V. If one confines one's attention to monoids (i.e. one-object V-categories), the basic results needed to develop the Azumaya-Brauer theory are quite simple: they reduce essentially to Morita theory in monoidal categories. Consequently, the conditions on V can be weaker than those assumed in our paper. For example, in the classical paper by Pareigis [20], the closedness of V is weakened, and in some recent papers by Van Oystaeyen and Zhang (see [22]) and by Alonso Alvarez et al. (see [1]), V is braided but not necessarily symmetric; however, some completeness and biclosedness requirements are needed on V.

They use very weak assumptions: they're looking at monoids in a symmetric monoidal category with coequalizers that are preserved by tensor products.

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 16:53):

This is why they need the coequalizers that I mentioned!

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 16:55):

If AAA is a monoid in a monoidal category C\mathsf{C}C with coequalizers, and AAA acts on the right on XXX and AAA acts on the right on YYY, you can define a thing X⊗AYX \otimes_A YX⊗A​Y using a coequalizer, copying the usual construction when C=Ab\mathsf{C} = \mathsf{Ab}C=Ab.

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 16:56):

Namely, you form the two obvious morphisms X⊗A⊗Y→X⊗YX \otimes A \otimes Y \to X \otimes YX⊗A⊗Y→X⊗Y and you coequalize them.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (May 27 2023 at 16:58):

Ok, and AAA acts on the right on XXX means that you have a morphism X⊗A→XX \otimes A \rightarrow XX⊗A→X which verifies the same diagrams than for a set XXX which would act on a monoid AAA, right?

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 17:02):

Yes, exactly.

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 17:06):

So in a symmetric monoidal category C\mathsf{C}C with equalizers preserved by taking tensor products with objects, we can talk about:

  • monoids in C\mathsf{C}C
  • left and right actions of a monoid A∈CA \in \mathsf{C}A∈C
  • the category of left actions of a monoid A∈CA \in \mathsf{C}A∈C, and similar for right actions
  • A,BA,BA,B-bimodules (or 'biactions') of a pair of monoids A,B∈CA,B \in \mathsf{C}A,B∈C
  • how to take an A,BA,BA,B-bimodule and a B,CB,CB,C-bimodule and tensor them over BBB to get an A,CA,CA,C-bimodule

and finally the monoidal bicategory of

  • monoids in C\mathsf{C}C
  • bimodules between such monoids
  • bimodule homomorphisms

This is a pretty general context for Azumaya--Brauer--Morita theory.

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 17:13):

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 17:14):

This abstract theory is very pretty and I'm basically glad people developed it to the point of defining "Azumaya monoids" in a bunch of equivalent ways.

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 17:19):

But I still think there should be a simple string diagram proof that these two concepts are equivalent:

1) a monoid AAA in C\mathsf{C}C for which there's a monoid BBB such that B⊗A≅IB \otimes A \cong IB⊗A≅I in the monoidal bicategory of monoids, bimodules and bimodule homomorphisms.

2) a monoid AAA that's separable (it's equipped with a section sss of the multiplication map m:A⊗A→Am: A \otimes A \to Am:A⊗A→A in the category of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules) and central: the canonical map p:A→Ap: A \to Ap:A→A projecting AAA down to its center (defined using sss) has image III.

John Baez (May 27 2023 at 17:25):

Item 2) could be somewhat wrong, and Vitale says it rather differently in that paper I linked to. After Proposition 1.3 he says a monoid AAA is Azumaya if and only if it is faithfully projective in the category of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules and the canonical arrow A⊗Aop→[A,A]A \otimes A^{\text{op}} \to [A,A]A⊗Aop→[A,A] is an isomorphism.

Here he's assuming C\mathsf{C}C is a closed symmetric monoidal category, and [A,A][A,A][A,A] is the internal hom. He uses a weird symbol for it... but not a lollipop.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:11):

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

I think there is no problem to express in string diagrams that 1) There exists an equivalence Aop⊗A∼IA^{op} \otimes A \sim IAop⊗A∼I for a monoid AAA and 2) there exists a section A→A⊗AA \rightarrow A \otimes AA→A⊗A of m:A⊗A→Am:A\otimes A \rightarrow Am:A⊗A→A such that mmm followed by the symmetry A⊗A→A⊗AA \otimes A \rightarrow A \otimes AA⊗A→A⊗A followed by the multiplication A⊗A→AA \otimes A \rightarrow AA⊗A→A is equal to the counit ϵ:A→I\epsilon:A \rightarrow Iϵ:A→I followed by the unit ι:I→A\iota:I \rightarrow Aι:I→A.

I have just one question. What is the definition of this counit?

That's a tricky and interesting question. I am most familiar with the case when our symmetric monoidal category C\mathsf{C}C is the category of finite-dimensional vector spaces over a field kkk so let me talk about that case first. Then AAA is a finite-dimensional algebra over a field. In this case we can always define a counit ϵ:A→k\epsilon: A \to kϵ:A→k as follows:

ϵ(a)=tr(La)\epsilon(a) = \mathrm{tr}(L_a) ϵ(a)=tr(La​)

where for any a∈Aa \in Aa∈A the map La:A→AL_a: A \to ALa​:A→A is given by left multiplication

La(b)=ab L_a(b) = a bLa​(b)=ab

You may enjoy showing

ϵ(ab)=ϵ(ba)\epsilon(a b) = \epsilon(b a) ϵ(ab)=ϵ(ba)

in this context.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:13):

It's easy to generalize this to the case where C\mathsf{C}C is any symmetric monoidal category and A∈CA \in \mathsf{C}A∈C is any monoid whose underlying object has a dual A∗A^\astA∗. That is, it's easy if you know about duals of objects in symmetric monoidal categories, and how they are used to define traces!

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:14):

As with any adjunction, the dual of an object in a symmetric monoidal category comes along with morphisms called the unit and counit, which are unfortunately completely different from the things I was calling the unit and counit here:

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:15):

there exists a section A→A⊗AA \rightarrow A \otimes AA→A⊗A of m:A⊗A→Am:A\otimes A \rightarrow Am:A⊗A→A such that mmm followed by the symmetry A⊗A→A⊗AA \otimes A \rightarrow A \otimes AA⊗A→A⊗A followed by the multiplication A⊗A→AA \otimes A \rightarrow AA⊗A→A is equal to the counit ϵ:A→I\epsilon:A \rightarrow Iϵ:A→I followed by the unit ι:I→A\iota:I \rightarrow Aι:I→A.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:18):

So let me use some other names! Our object AAA and its dual A∗A^\astA∗ - which I'm assuming exists :warning: - come with morphisms

μ:I→A⊗A∗ \mu: I \to A \otimes A^\ast μ:I→A⊗A∗
η:A∗⊗A→I \eta : A^\ast \otimes A \to I η:A∗⊗A→I

often called the unit and counit, obeying the [[triangle identities]].

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:24):

Because AAA is a monoid with with multiplication m:A→Am: A \to Am:A→A we can form this composite:

A→1A⊗μA⊗A⊗A∗→m⊗1A∗A⊗A∗→SA,A∗A∗⊗A→ηI A \xrightarrow{1_A \otimes \mu} A \otimes A \otimes A^\ast \xrightarrow{m \otimes 1_{A^\ast}} A \otimes A^\ast \xrightarrow{S_{A,A^\ast}} A^\ast \otimes A \xrightarrow{\eta} I A1A​⊗μ​A⊗A⊗A∗m⊗1A∗​​A⊗A∗SA,A∗​​A∗⊗Aη​I

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:24):

And this is the thing I was calling ϵ:A→I\epsilon: A \to Iϵ:A→I.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:27):

In the long composite above I'm using the symmetry SA,A∗:A⊗A∗→A∗⊗AS_{A,A^\ast}: A \otimes A^\ast \to A^\ast \otimes ASA,A∗​:A⊗A∗→A∗⊗A.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:30):

It's a fun exercise to check that when AAA is a monoid in the symmetric monoidal category of finite-dimensional vector spaces, this definition of ϵ:A→I\epsilon: A \to Iϵ:A→I agrees with the one I mentioned before:

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:31):

ϵ(a)=tr(La)\epsilon(a) = \mathrm{tr}(L_a) ϵ(a)=tr(La​)

where for any a∈Aa \in Aa∈A the map La:A→AL_a: A \to ALa​:A→A is given by left multiplication

La(b)=ab L_a(b) = a bLa​(b)=ab

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:32):

In short: we get ϵ:A→I\epsilon: A \to Iϵ:A→I whenever AAA has a dual. So the next question is: why, in our general abstract nonsense situation, should an Azumaya monoid have a dual?

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:33):

But that's a bit hard too, and I'm worn out for now.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 00:44):

By the way, I find this thing:

A→1A⊗μA⊗A⊗A∗→m⊗1A∗A⊗A∗→SA,A∗A∗⊗A→ηI A \xrightarrow{1_A \otimes \mu} A \otimes A \otimes A^\ast \xrightarrow{m \otimes 1_{A^\ast}} A \otimes A^\ast \xrightarrow{S_{A,A^\ast}} A^\ast \otimes A \xrightarrow{\eta} I A1A​⊗μ​A⊗A⊗A∗m⊗1A∗​​A⊗A∗SA,A∗​​A∗⊗Aη​I

to be much clearer using string diagrams. I did a bunch of related string diagram calculations on pages 82-85 here.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 20:47):

A correction:

John Baez said:

Say AAA is the algebra of n×nn \times nn×n matrices with entries in RRR. Let eij∈Ae_{i j} \in Aeij​∈A be the elementary matrices. Then here's a A,AA,AA,A-bimodule homomorphism

A↦A⊗RAA \mapsto A \otimes_R A A↦A⊗R​A

that's a right inverse for multiplication:

eij↦1n∑k=1neik⊗ekj e_{ij} \mapsto \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^n e_{ik} \otimes e_{kj}eij​↦n1​∑k=1n​eik​⊗ekj​

But notice, this only works if we can divide by nnn in RRR.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 20:49):

In fact there's an A,AA,AA,A-bimodule homomorphism that's a right inverse for multiplication even if we can't divide by nnn.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 20:50):

The trick is to define it by

1↦∑ieij⊗eji 1 \mapsto \sum_i e_{i j} \otimes e_{j i} 1↦∑i​eij​⊗eji​

where we don't sum over jjj.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 20:53):

Then, for it to be a left AAA-module homomorphism it must do this:

ekℓ↦∑iekℓeij⊗eji=ekj⊗ejℓ e_{k \ell} \mapsto \sum_i e_{k \ell} e_{ij} \otimes e_{ji} = e_{kj} \otimes e_{j \ell} ekℓ​↦∑i​ekℓ​eij​⊗eji​=ekj​⊗ejℓ​

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 20:54):

For it to be a right AAA-module homomorphism it must do this:

ekℓ↦∑ieij⊗ejiekℓ=ekj⊗ejℓ e_{k\ell} \mapsto \sum_i e_{ij} \otimes e_{ji} e_{k \ell} = e_{kj} \otimes e_{j \ell} ekℓ​↦∑i​eij​⊗eji​ekℓ​=ekj​⊗ejℓ​

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 20:55):

Luckily these agree. So we use this as our rule for the map, and it's easy to see that multiplication sends ekj⊗ejℓe_{k j} \otimes e_{j \ell}ekj​⊗ejℓ​ back to ekℓe_{k\ell}ekℓ​.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 20:56):

This choice of splitting is scarily arbitrary since it depends on a choice of jjj.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 20:57):

To avoid the arbitrariness we could sum over all jjj and then divide by nnn... which is what I suggested before... but that only works if nnn is invertible in our ring RRR.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:13):

Okay, I think my earlier remarks involving the center of a separable algebra were a bit wrong-headed. I think this paper has a better idea:

  • Enrico M. Vitale, The Brauer and Brauer-Taylor groups of a symmetric monoidal category, 1996.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:16):

I'm used to working with finite-dimensional separable algebras over a field, and there I can freely use the duals of those algebras - that is, their dual vector spaces - and the fact that finite-dimensional vector spaces form a [[compact closed category]]. But working over a general ring, or in a general symmetric monoidal category, it becomes questionable whether we're allowed to assume our separable algebras have duals.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:16):

There's even the question of whether separable algebras over a field are automatically finite-dimensional or not!

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:17):

It seems they are - but the proof is rather hard:

  • Is a "separable" algebra over a field finite-dimensional?

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:20):

This is different from [[Frobenius algebras]], where it's really easy to see they are finite-dimensional. All the [[separable algebras]] I really understand well are Frobenius algebras. These two concepts are deeply related, as you can see from the nLab articles (which I helped write back when I was using these algebras to study TQFT).

But when @Jean-Baptiste Vienney asked me to cough up the counit for an arbitrary separable algebra, I choked! Even working over a field, I couldn't do it without assuming the algebra is finite-dimensional!

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:23):

Luckily, Vitale has a better approach. Let's work in a [[Benabou cosmos]] C\mathsf{C}C, meaning a symmetric monoidal closed category C\mathsf{C}C with small limits and colimits. A cosmos is a gold-plated sort of category that makes everything nice. We can reduce the assumptions later if we actually prove anything interesting!

In a cosmos C\mathsf{C}C, Vitale claims the following are equivalent:

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:25):

  1. Azumaya monoids, defined as monoids A∈CA \in \mathsf{C}A∈C that have a tensor inverse up to Morita equivalence, meaning a monoid BBB such that A⊗B≅IA \otimes B \cong IA⊗B≅I in the bicategory of monoids in C\mathsf{C}C, bimodules, and bimodule homomorphsms.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:36):

  1. Monoids A∈CA \in \mathsf{C}A∈C that are faithfully projective in the category of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules and have the property that the obvious morphism I→[A,A]I \to [A,A]I→[A,A] in the category of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules is an isomorphism.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:37):

Now, the second one looks rather scary and technical to me, but I'm slowly learning to love it.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:39):

For starters, the category of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules is monoidal closed, so it has an internal hom, which I'm denoting by [−,−][-,-][−,−].

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:42):

(If you don't like bimodules remember that an X,YX,YX,Y-bimodule is the same as an X⊗YopX \otimes Y^{\mathrm{op}}X⊗Yop-module, so bimodules can be seen as a special sort of modules. And in a symmetric monoidal category C\mathsf{C}C that's a cosmos, I'm pretty sure any monoid XXX has a closed monoidal category of modules!)

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (May 28 2023 at 21:47):

The property that I→[A,A]I \rightarrow [A,A]I→[A,A] is an isomorphism is very strong, in the category of finite dimensional vector space, it means that AAA is one-dimensional... if I'm not mistaken.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:48):

You didn't yet read my explanation of what I meant by [−,−][-,-][−,−].

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:48):

If I meant the internal hom in C\mathsf{C}C then you'd be correct.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:49):

Let me explain what [A,A][A,A][A,A] is actually like when C=Vect\mathsf{C} = \mathsf{Vect}C=Vect. (By the way, finite-dimensional vector spaces don't form a cosmos. It's not a big deal, but it's worth noting.)

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:50):

So, when C=Vect\mathsf{C} = \mathsf{Vect}C=Vect, AAA is an algebra, and [A,A][A,A][A,A] is the algebra of all linear maps f:A→Af: A \to Af:A→A that are actually A,AA,AA,A-bimodule endomorphisms:

af(b)c=f(abc) a f(b) c = f(abc) af(b)c=f(abc)

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:51):

Every left AAA-module endomorphism of AAA is right multiplication by some element of AAA, so we know

f(b)=bxf (b) = b x f(b)=bx

for some fixed x∈Ax \in Ax∈A.

Then af(b)c=f(abc)a f(b) c = f(abc)af(b)c=f(abc) implies xxx in the center of AAA!

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (May 28 2023 at 21:52):

Oh, I see, ok, I was thinking to I,II,II,I-bimodule endomorphisms.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:53):

Okay.

So: [A,A][A,A][A,A] is just the center of AAA in this case!

Jean-Baptiste Vienney (May 28 2023 at 21:54):

Ohhh, so this condition is the one that the center of AAA is III like before, it makes sense!

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:54):

Right: saying the "obvious" map I→[A,A]I \to [A,A]I→[A,A] (I hope it's actually obvious) is an isomorphism, is saying that the center of AAA consists just of scalars, i.e. elements of I=kI = kI=k, where kkk is our field.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:55):

But I don't think I used anything special about fields here; I believe everything I just said works when C\mathsf{C}C is modules of any commutative ring RRR.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:56):

So in this class of examples - the "classical" examples - we have a nice way of saying that the center of our RRR-algebra AAA is just RRR.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:56):

Such algebras are called central.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 21:57):

So, in general, we'll say a monoid A∈CA \in \mathsf{C}A∈C is central when the obvious morphism of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules I→[A,A]I \to [A,A]I→[A,A] is an isomorphism!

Puzzle 1. - if A,BA,BA,B are central monoids in a cosmos C\mathsf{C}C, is A⊗BA \otimes BA⊗B central?

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 22:00):

In the case where C=Vect\mathsf{C} = \mathsf{Vect}C=Vect, this is true. And it's also easy to see that the tensor product of Azumaya monoids is Azumaya, so if 1. and 2. are really equivalent (like Benabou and Vitale claim), it's at least reasonable to hope that the tensor product of central monoids is central, even though it doesn't actually follow, since an Azumaya monoid is a central monoid with some extra property.

John Baez (May 28 2023 at 22:02):

If someone digs into Puzzle 1 they'll probably start wondering how [A⊗B,A⊗B][A \otimes B, A \otimes B][A⊗B,A⊗B] is related to [A,A][A,A][A,A] and [B,B][B,B][B,B]. Just remember that [−,−][-,-][−,−] means something different in each expression!!!

Okay, so I was going insane. The set of A,AA,AA,A-bimodule morphisms from AAA to AAA is only an A,AA,AA,A-bimodule when AAA is commutative.

John Baez (May 29 2023 at 01:47):

For example suppose f:A→Af: A \to Af:A→A is an A,AA,AA,A-bimodule morphism:

f(abc)=af(b)c f(abc) = a f(b) c f(abc)=af(b)c

John Baez (May 29 2023 at 01:48):

Then multiplying fff on the left (or right) by an element x∈Ax \in Ax∈A ruins this property:

xf(abc)≠a xf(b) c xf (abc) \ne a \, xf(b) \,c xf(abc)=axf(b)c

John Baez (May 29 2023 at 01:53):

So, given a monoid AAA in the cosmos C\mathsf{C}C and A,AA,AA,A-bimodules XXX and YYY in this cosmos, I believe Vitale wants [X,Y][X,Y][X,Y] to be the C\mathsf{C}C-object of A,AA,AA,A-bimodule morphisms from XXX to YYY. It's not an A,AA,AA,A-bimodule itself, just an object in C\mathsf{C}C.

John Baez (May 29 2023 at 01:57):

However, [X,X][X,X][X,X] is better: it's a monoid object in C\mathsf{C}C!

John Baez (May 29 2023 at 01:57):

And so it has a unit I→[X,X]I \to [X,X]I→[X,X].

John Baez (May 29 2023 at 01:57):

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 00:33):

Whoops, first I have to take a walk. :big_frown:

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 02:27):

Okay, let me start with the general context. Let's take V to be a very nice symmetric monoidal category: closed, complete and cocomplete. This is what Benabou called a cosmos.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 02:46):

There is then a bicategory VMod where:

  • objects are V-enriched categories (or V-categories for short)
  • morphisms are V-enriched profunctors (or V-profunctors)
  • 2-morphisms are V-enriched natural transformations between V-enriched profunctors (or simply V-natural transformations).

I will try to remember to write ↛\nrightarrow↛ for V-profunctors and →\to→ for V-enriched functors (or V-functors, for short).

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 02:47):

I don't know good references for these facts:

Theorem 1 VMod is a symmetric monoidal bicategory.

Theorem 2. VMod is compact closed.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 02:49):

Here's a good place to see the definitions spelled out:

  • Mike Stay, Compact closed bicategories.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 02:52):

The example that looms large in my mind is V = RMod, the category of modules of a commutative ring, with the usual tensor product M⊗RNM \otimes_R NM⊗R​N of modules giving the symmetric monoidal structure.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 02:55):

In this case

  • a one-object V-category is called an algebra over R,
  • a V-enriched profunctor between these is called a bimodule,
  • a V-natural transformation is called a bimodule homomorphism.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 02:56):

When V = RMod we can more generally call a V-enriched category an algebroid over R, but there's vastly more literature on algebras.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 03:01):

I'm trying to understand Azumaya algebras, but the general concept is this:

Definition. A V-category C is Azumaya if there is a V-category D such that C ⊗\otimes⊗ D ≃\simeq≃ I in VMod.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 03:02):

Here ⊗\otimes⊗ is the tensor product of V-enriched categories and I is the unit for this tensor product. So Azumaya V-categories are, morally speaking, the invertible ones.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 03:03):

But notice that ≃\simeq≃ stands for equivalence in the bicategory VMod, so Azumaya V-categories need only be invertible up to equivalence.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 03:06):

My goal, ultimately, is to find nice proofs of a bunch of facts about Azumaya V-categories. Some of these facts are already known. One-object Azumaya V-categories where V = RMod for a commutative ring are called Azumaya algebras and there are some very interesting theorems about these.

Now I already said that VMod is compact closed. This means that every V-category CCC has a dual C∗C^\astC∗ which comes with a unit

ι:I↛C⊗C∗ \iota: I \nrightarrow C \otimes C^\astι:I↛C⊗C∗

and counit

ϵ:C∗⊗C↛I \epsilon: C^\ast \otimes C \nrightarrow I ϵ:C∗⊗C↛I

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 03:07):

which obey the usual triangle identities up to isomorphism.

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 03:10):

In other words, they form a biadjunction. (The isomorphisms I alluded to can always be improved to obey some laws of their own called the 'swallowtail identities' - but this may not ever matter to us, though it would be fun for me if it did.)

John Baez (Jun 01 2023 at 03:13):

Now, there's another fundamental result that I don't know a reference for:

Theorem 3. Any two duals of an object in a symmetric monoidal bicategory are equivalent. Given a V-category CCC, the opposite V-category CopC^{\text{op}}Cop, defined in a way analogous to the usual opposite of a category, serves as a dual for CCC in VMod.

Theorem 3. Given a V-category CCC, the opposite V-category CopC^{\text{op}}Cop, defined in a way analogous to the usual opposite of a category, serves as a dual for CCC in VMod. The counit

ϵ:Cop⊗C↛I\epsilon: C^{\text{op}} \otimes C \nrightarrow Iϵ:Cop⊗C↛I

can be taken to be the hom of CCC, which is the V-functor

hom: Cop⊗C→VC^{\text{op}} \otimes C \to V Cop⊗C→V

Furthermore, we can twist around this V-profunctor and get the unit

ι:I↛C⊗Cop \iota: I \nrightarrow C \otimes C^{\text{op}} ι:I↛C⊗Cop

Mike Shulman (Jun 01 2023 at 04:21):

John Baez said:

Theorem 1 VMod is a symmetric monoidal bicategory.

One way to prove this, which I unsurprisingly happen to think is nice and clean, is to combine Framed bicategories and monoidal fibrations with Constructing symmetric monoidal bicategories. In example 15.4 of FBMF I observed that if you make a symmetric monoidal category VVV indexed/fibered over Set\rm SetSet in the canonical way by taking families of objects, then it is frameable so you can make it into a double category, and then that double category has local coequalizers so you can take the double category of monoids and modules therein, which is your VModV\rm ModVMod. In the symmetric case all the monoidal structures carry through, so you can then apply CSMB to make the symmetric monoidal double category into a symmetric monoidal bicategory.

This fact was of course known to category theorists (particularly Australians) long before my papers, but I don't actually know of another place where it is proven carefully.

Mike Shulman (Jun 01 2023 at 04:24):

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

(Ok, my intuition is that all of this will not use any "infinity" but I'm maybe mistaken. Mathematicians often suppose that some category is "complete" or "cocomplete" instead of simply supposing that all the limit and colimit they use exist which would be better.)

If you want a bicategory VModV\rm ModVMod whose objects are arbitrary small VVV-categories, then you need VVV to have arbitrary small colimits in order to define composition of VVV-profunctors. You can get away with finite colimits if you restrict the objects of VModV\rm ModVMod to be VVV-categories with finitely many objects. Or you can try to use something like a [[virtual double category]] instead, but that doesn't work so well for duality theory.

Mike Shulman (Jun 01 2023 at 04:32):

John Baez said:

Theorem 2. VMod is compact closed.
...
Theorem 3. Given a V-category CCC, the opposite V-category CopC^{\text{op}}Cop, defined in a way analogous to the usual opposite of a category, serves as a dual for CCC in VMod.

I'm not sure how one could prove theorem 2 without proving theorem 3 (which should have theorem 2 as an immediate consequence). One fairly early reference for this is section 7 of Day & Street's Monoidal bicategories and Hopf algebroids (1997), but they don't give any more details of the proof than you did. I don't offhand know of somewhere that gives more details.

Right. For anyone who wants to see a string diagram proof of what we're talking about here, try the pictures in the proof of Theorem 14 on page 19 here. Here we've got a monoidal category where every object xxx has an object x‾\overline{x}x with isomorphisms x⊗x‾≅x‾⊗x≅Ix \otimes \overline{x} \cong \overline{x} \otimes x \cong Ix⊗x≅x⊗x≅I, and we improve one of those isomorphisms in order to make x‾\overline{x}x into the dual of xxx - i.e., in order to get isomorphisms obeying the [[triangle identities]]. The argument is visually quite pretty.

I think now I'll break down and use F:A↛BF: A \nrightarrow BF:A↛B to mean FFF is a V-profunctor and F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B to mean FFF is a V-functor, at least for a while.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 01:37):

So, any V-profunctor F:A↛BF : A \nrightarrow BF:A↛B is (by definition) a V-functor from A⊗BopA \otimes B^{\mathrm{op}} A⊗Bop to VVV, which amounts to the same thing as V-functors from AAA to B^\hat{B}B^, the V-category of V-functors from BopB^{\text{op}}Bop to V.

B^\hat{B}B^ is called the category of V-enriched presheaves on BBB.

By a spinoff of the enriched Yoneda lemma, V-functors from AAA to B^\hat{B}B^ in turn amount to the same thing as cocontinuous V-functors from A^\hat{A}A^ to B^\hat{B}B^.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 01:47):

So, the symmetric monoidal bicategory I've been calling VMod, where

  • objects are V-categories
  • morphisms are V-profunctors
  • 2-morphisms are V-natural transformations

is equivalent to one where

  • objects are V-categories
  • morphisms from AAA to BBB are cocontinuous V-functors from A^\hat{A}A^ to B^\hat{B}B^
  • 2-morphisms are V-natural transformations

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 01:49):

So we get a new viewpoint on VMod. From this new viewpoint, what does it mean to say a V-category CCC is Azumaya?

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 01:51):

In the old viewpoint CCC is Azumaya if its hom, made into a V-profunctor from Cop⊗CC^{\text{op}} \otimes CCop⊗C to VVV, is an equivalence in VMod.

Mike Shulman (Jun 02 2023 at 01:55):

Don't you mean a VVV-profunctor from Cop⊗CC^{\rm op}\otimes CCop⊗C to III, the unit VVV-category?

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 01:56):

Yes. Thanks:

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 01:56):

In the old viewpoint CCC is Azumaya if its hom, made into a V-profunctor from Cop⊗CC^{\text{op}} \otimes CCop⊗C to III, is an equivalence in VMod.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 02:07):

In the new viewpoint it means this. By the universal property of V=I^V = \hat{I}V=I^, we can take the hom V-functor

hom:Cop⊗C→V \mathrm{hom}: C^{\text{op}} \otimes C \to V hom:Cop⊗C→V

and extend it to a cocontinuous V-functor

Cop⊗C^→V \widehat{ C^{\text{op}} \otimes C} \to V Cop⊗C​→V

Then CCC is Azumaya iff this cocontinous V-functor is an equivalence.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:04):

Let's summarize and look at an example:

Corollary 6. A V-category CCC is Azumaya iff when we extend the V-functor hom:Cop⊗C→V \mathrm{hom}: C^{\text{op}} \otimes C \to V hom:Cop⊗C→V to a cocontinuous V-functor hom^:Cop⊗C^→V \widehat{\mathrm{hom}}: \widehat{ C^{\text{op}} \otimes C} \to V hom:Cop⊗C​→V, then hom^\widehat{\mathrm{hom}}hom is an equivalence of V-categories.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:08):

Since this looks a bit scary let's do the example where VVV is the category of modules of some commutative ring R and CCC is a one-object V-category. As we've seen, such a one-object V-category amounts to the same thing as an (associative unital) R-algebra, say A.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:09):

Then C^\widehat{C}C is the V-category of right modules of A.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:11):

Similarly the one-object V-category Cop⊗CC^{\text{op}} \otimes CCop⊗C is what we'd normally call the R-algebra Aop⊗AA^{\text{op}} \otimes AAop⊗A. So the monstrosity Cop⊗C^\widehat{C^{\text{op}} \otimes C}Cop⊗C​ is what we'd normally call the V-category of right modules of Aop⊗AA^{\text{op}} \otimes AAop⊗A - or better yet, the V-category of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:15):

So this scary-looking thing

hom^:Cop⊗C^→V \widehat{\mathrm{hom}}: \widehat{ C^{\text{op}} \otimes C} \to V hom:Cop⊗C​→V

maps any A,a-bimodule to some R-module. And if you unwind all the abstractions you see it works like this: it maps any A,A-bimodule MMM to the R-module hom^(M,M)\widehat{\mathrm{hom}}(M,M)hom(M,M), which consists of all A,A-bimodule endomorphisms of M.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:18):

In summary, we've gotten this:

Corollary 6. For a commutative ring R, an R-algebra A is Azumaya iff the enriched functor sending any A,A-bimodule to its R-module of A,A-bimodule endomorphisms is an equivalence.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:18):

So that was an example! But category theory is the subject where the examples need examples. So let's do an example of this corollary.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:20):

Let's take R to be the ring of real numbers. Since is the boldest of rings we call it R\mathbb{R}R.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:36):

And let's take our R\mathbb{R}R-algebra A to be - you guessed it! - the quaternions, H\mathbb{H}H.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:41):

A good example of an H,H\mathbb{H},\mathbb{H}H,H bimodule is H\mathbb{H}H.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:42):

hom^(H,H)\widehat{\mathrm{hom}}(\mathbb{H},\mathbb{H})hom(H,H) consists of all H,H\mathbb{H},\mathbb{H}H,H-bimodule endomorphisms of H\mathbb{H}H.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:45):

By the ring theory analogue of Cayley's theorem, all the left H\mathbb{H}H-module endomorphisms of H\mathbb{H}H are given by right multiplication by guys in H\mathbb{H}H. And all the right H\mathbb{H}H-module endomorphisms of H\mathbb{H}H are given by left multiplication by guys in H\mathbb{H}H.

So every H,H\mathbb{H},\mathbb{H}H,H bimodule endomorphism is just multiplication by some element of the center of H\mathbb{H}H!

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:47):

But the center of H\mathbb{H}H is just R\mathbb{R}R, so we get

hom^(H,H)≅R\widehat{\mathrm{hom}}(\mathbb{H},\mathbb{H}) \cong \mathbb{R}hom(H,H)≅R

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:51):

So far I haven't used anything special about the quaternions. But next, every H,H\mathbb{H},\mathbb{H}H,H-bimodule is isomorphic to a sum of copies of H\mathbb{H}H.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:52):

Similarly, every R\mathbb{R}R-module is a sum of copies of R\mathbb{R}R.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:54):

And hom^\widehat{\mathrm{hom}}hom sends the sum of κ\kappaκ copies of H\mathbb{H}H to the sum of κ\kappaκ copies of R\mathbb{R}R since it's cocontinuous.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:56):

So with a little work we can show hom^\widehat{\mathrm{hom}}hom is an equivalence from the (enriched) category of H,H\mathbb{H},\mathbb{H}H,H-bimodules to the (enriched) category of R\mathbb{R}R-modules.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:57):

So, by Corollary 6, the quaternions are an Azumaya algebra over the reals!

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 04:58):

This may not be the slickest way to show that fact... but this example is helping me understand Corollary 6.

corresponds to the unit and counit profunctors

ϵ ⁣:Cop⊗C↛Iι ⁣:I↛C⊗Cop.\epsilon \colon C^{\mathrm{op}} \otimes C \nrightarrow I\\ \iota \colon I \nrightarrow C \otimes C^{\mathrm{op}} .ϵ:Cop⊗C↛Iι:I↛C⊗Cop.

Simon Willerton (Jun 02 2023 at 18:27):

One comment about your [A,A][A, A][A,A]. This is the set of 2-morphisms 2hom(idA,idA)2\mathrm{hom}(\mathrm{id}_A, \mathrm{id}_A)2hom(idA​,idA​). In my old terminology this is the 'diagonal trace' of the identity 1-cell on AAA, or the 'diagonal dimension' of AAAAAA, as we think of the trace of the identity as giving the dimension.

If we are thinking of Vmod as a bicategory then a priori this 2-hom should be a set. However, for 'nice' bicategories, the hom-categories, like hom(A,A)\mathbf{hom}(A, A)hom(A,A) have a canonical enrichment in the category of scalars hom(I,I)\mathbf{hom}(I, I)hom(I,I), and for Vmod this category of scalars is precisely VVV.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 18:49):

Okay, let's keep going!

Before I dive into "central" and "separable" algebras and their generalizations to V-categories, I want to mention a nice result for R-algebras, meaning associative unital algebras over some commutative ring R.

Theorem 7. The A,B-bimodule M is a left adjoint in the bicategory of R-algebras, bimodules and bimodule homomorphisms iff M is finitely generated and projective as a left B-module.

This is stated without proof as Proposition 2.3 in Borceux and Vitale's Azumaya categories. By now @Todd Trimble has given me a couple of proofs: "ring theorist's proofs" that use known stuff about algebras and their modules, and "category theorist's proofs" that use the conceptual description of finitely generated projective B-modules as precisely those lying in the [[Cauchy completion]] of the one-object RMod-category B.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 18:51):

I still want to understand this result better, but for now let's see what we can do with it.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 18:54):

By definition A is Azumaya iff there's an equivalence

ϵ:Aop⊗A↛I \epsilon: A^{\text{op}} \otimes A \nrightarrow I ϵ:Aop⊗A↛I
ι:I↛A⊗Aop\iota: I \nrightarrow A \otimes A^{\text{op}} ι:I↛A⊗Aop

in our bicategory of V-categories, V-profunctors and V-natural transformations where V = RMod.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 19:01):

I've also pointed out that we can assume without loss of generality that ϵ\epsilonϵ comes from the hom-functor hom:Aop⊗A→V\mathrm{hom}: A^{\text{op}} \otimes A \to Vhom:Aop⊗A→V.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 19:05):

But we can always enhance any equivalence in a bicategory to an adjunction, in fact taking either arrow to be the left adjoint and massaging the other until it becomes the right adjoint. So as a consequence of all these facts we get

Corollary 8. An R-algebra A is Azumaya iff the V-profunctor ϵ:Aop⊗A↛I\epsilon: A^{\text{op}} \otimes A \nrightarrow Iϵ:Aop⊗A↛I coming from the hom V-functor hom:Aop⊗A→V\mathrm{hom}: A^{\text{op}} \otimes A \to Vhom:Aop⊗A→V is a left adjoint equivalence.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 19:08):

So assume A is Azumaya. By Theorem 7, we must have

ϵ≅M⊗Aop⊗A− \epsilon \cong M \otimes_{A^{\text{op}} \otimes A} - ϵ≅M⊗Aop⊗A​−

for some left III, right Aop⊗A{A^{\text{op}} \otimes A}Aop⊗A module MMM which is finitely generated and projective!

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 19:10):

But every object in any monoidal bicategory is automatically a left I-module in just one way (up to isomorphism) so we don't even need to bother saying "left I".

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 19:11):

A right Aop⊗AA^{\text{op}} \otimes AAop⊗A-module is the same as an A,AA,AA,A-bimodule, if that makes you feel better.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 19:12):

So the main takeaway is that whenever we've got an Azumaya algebra AAA, there's a finitely generated projective object MMM in the category of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules that attests to this.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 19:13):

But we don't have to roam around the universe looking for this MMM. After all, we knew that ϵ\epsilonϵ came from the hom of AAA.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 19:14):

So this A,AA,AA,A-bimodule MMM must be something canonically associated to AAA itself.

John Baez (Jun 02 2023 at 19:15):

But the most obvious A,AA,AA,A-bimodule associated to AAA is just AAA! So I'll guess that MMM is just AAA.

Is that right?

Simon Willerton (Jun 04 2023 at 13:03):

Aside/Digression: You said that if AAA is Azumaya then the centre of AAA is isomorphic to RRR. I note that that's the same as saying the 'diagonal dimension' of AAA is RRR.

Is it true that the abelianization (commutativization?) of AAA is also isomorphic to RRR? So is A/{ab=ba}≅RA/\{ab = ba\} \cong RA/{ab=ba}≅R?

We have a compact closed symmetric monoidal bicategory so we can take the 'categorical trace' of any 1-endomorphism M ⁣:A↛AM\colon A\nrightarrow AM:A↛A and this trace is an object in the category of scalars hom(I,I)≅mod(R)\mathbf{hom}(I,I) \cong \text{mod}(R)hom(I,I)≅mod(R). I call this the 'round trace' as it looks like a circle when you draw it in string diagrams. In particular we can take the round trace of the identity 1-morphism. The identity morphism A↛AA \nrightarrow AA↛A is the bimodule AAA{}_A A_{A}A​AA​ and its round trace (aka the round dimension of AAA) is precisely the abelianization of AAA.

But the round trace of the identity should just be the composite I↛A⊗Aop↛Aop⊗A↛II \nrightarrow A \otimes A^{\text{op}} \nrightarrow A^{\text{op}} \otimes A \nrightarrow II↛A⊗Aop↛Aop⊗A↛I where the arrows are ι\iotaι, the symmetry and ϵ\epsilonϵ. The arrows are all equivalences, so the composite, ie the trace, should be (quasi) invertible in hom(I,I)≅mod(R)\mathbf{hom}(I, I) \cong \text{mod}(R)hom(I,I)≅mod(R). What's that going to be, other than RRR? :smiley: (Well, maybe something else interesting!)

Simon Willerton (Jun 04 2023 at 13:05):

Here invertible means with respect to the composition monoidal product in hom(I,I)\mathbf{hom}(I,I)hom(I,I) which corresponds to the tensor product of RRR-modules in mod(R)\text{mod}(R)mod(R).

Yes, it looks like I was being sloppy, but you guessed correctly. This ϵ\epsilonϵ here is a 1-morphism in the bicategory of cocontinuous functors between module categories. It came from a like-named 1-morphism in the bicategory of bimodules between algebras, which is an equivalent bicategory.

The point was: since this 1-morphism is a left adjoint, by Theorem 7 the bimodule must be finitely generated and projective as a module over one of the two algebras that acts on it.

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 16:18):

To add to the confusion, I got tangled up in the question of whether our module categories should be left module categories or right module categories! Ultimately I got pressured by various forces to use right module categories, but I didn't get it all straightened out. So for consistency with myself I should probably have written

ϵ≅−⊗Aop⊗AM \epsilon \cong - \otimes_{A^{\text{op}} \otimes A} M ϵ≅−⊗Aop⊗A​M

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 16:41):

Anyway, when all is said and done, I believe the upshot is this:

Theorem 9. Suppose AAA is an Azumaya algebra over the commutative ring RRR. Then the counit ϵ:Aop⊗A↛I\epsilon: A^{\text{op}} \otimes A \nrightarrow Iϵ:Aop⊗A↛I is an equivalence hence a left adjoint, so AAA is finitely generated and projective as a right III-module (i.e. an RRR-module). Furthermore the unit ι:I↛A⊗Aop\iota: I \nrightarrow A \otimes A^{\text{op}}ι:I↛A⊗Aop is an equivalence hence a left adjoint, so AAA is finitely generated and projective as a right A⊗Aop A \otimes A^{\text{op}}A⊗Aop-module.

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 16:47):

If anyone was paying careful attention, they'll see I'm trying to correct some earlier mistakes here:

  • the counit being a left adjoint forces AAA to be f.g. projective as an RRR-module,

while

  • the unit being a left adjoint forces AAA to be f.g. projective as an A⊗AopA \otimes A^{\text{op}}A⊗Aop-module.

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 16:53):

For Azumaya algebras these are both true. Over a field, the first just says any Azumaya algebra must be finite-dimensional. The second is a bit more exciting.

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 16:55):

So, we make up a definition:

Definition. An algebra AAA over a commutative ring is separable if it is f.g. projective as an A⊗AopA \otimes A^{\text{op}}A⊗Aop-module.

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 17:14):

But every algebra AAA is finitely generated as an A⊗AopA \otimes A^{\text{op}}A⊗Aop-module since it's generated by 1: every element is 1 times something in A⊗AopA \otimes A^{\text{op}}A⊗Aop.

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 17:16):

So people usually just say

Definition. An algebra AAA over a commutative ring is separable if it is projective as an A⊗AopA \otimes A^{\text{op}}A⊗Aop-module.

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 17:19):

Then there's an equivalent characterization which is quite practical and looks very beautiful in terms of string diagrams! This is what I really like:

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 17:29):

Theorem 10. An algebra AAA over a commutative ring is separable if and only if the multiplication m:A⊗A→Am: A \otimes A \to Am:A⊗A→A has a section (= right inverse) s:A→A⊗As: A \to A \otimes As:A→A⊗A that is an A,AA,AA,A-bimodule homomorphism.

Notice that A,AA,AA,A-bimodules and homomorphisms between these are equivalent to A⊗AopA \otimes A^{\text{op}}A⊗Aop-modules and homomorphisms between these; I'm just sick of writing that "op". I'm treating A⊗AA \otimes AA⊗A as an A,AA,AA,A-bimodule like this:

a(b⊗c)a′=ab⊗ca′ a (b \otimes c) a' = ab \otimes c a'a(b⊗c)a′=ab⊗ca′

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 17:30):

Proof of Theorem 10.   ⟹  \implies⟹: For any algebra AAA multiplication gives an epimorphism

A⊗A→mA→0 A \otimes A \xrightarrow{m} A \to 0A⊗Am​A→0

in the category of A,AA,AA,A-bimodules. Since A⊗AA \otimes AA⊗A is the free A,AA,AA,A-bimodule on one generator, if mmm has a section

A⊗A←sA→0 A \otimes A \xleftarrow{s} A \to 0A⊗As​A→0

then AAA is a summand of a free A,AA,AA,A-bimodule, hence it's projective. (If you know these facts for modules but not bimodules, remember that

⟸\Longleftarrow⟸: If AAA is projective as an A,AA,AA,A-bimodule, the epimorphism

A⊗A→mA→0 A \otimes A \xrightarrow{m} A \to 0A⊗Am​A→0

splits, and the splitting is our desired section s:A→A⊗As: A \to A \otimes As:A→A⊗A. \qquad :purple_square:

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 18:47):

Simon Willerton said:

Aside/Digression: You said that if AAA is Azumaya then the centre of AAA is isomorphic to RRR. I note that that's the same as saying the 'diagonal dimension' of AAA is RRR.

Is it true that the abelianization (commutativization?) of AAA is also isomorphic to RRR? So is A/{ab=ba}≅RA/\{ab = ba\} \cong RA/{ab=ba}≅R?

I don't know!

We have a compact closed symmetric monoidal bicategory so we can take the 'categorical trace' of any 1-endomorphism M ⁣:A↛AM\colon A\nrightarrow AM:A↛A and this trace is an object in the category of scalars hom(I,I)≅mod(R)\mathbf{hom}(I,I) \cong \text{mod}(R)hom(I,I)≅mod(R). I call this the 'round trace' as it looks like a circle when you draw it in string diagrams. In particular we can take the round trace of the identity 1-morphism. The identity morphism A↛AA \nrightarrow AA↛A is the bimodule AAA{}_A A_{A}A​AA​ and its round trace (aka the round dimension of AAA) is precisely the abelianization of AAA.

Simon Willerton (Jun 04 2023 at 19:51):

John Baez said:

Does that seem right? In other words: is there some natural algebra structure on the zeroth Hochschild homology of an algebra, or at least an Azumaya algebra?

In general, the zeroth Hochschild homology of an algebra is not an algebra. The zeroth Hochschild cohomology of an algebra is an algebra in general - it's the centre of the algebra, which is a subalgebra.

Simon Willerton (Jun 04 2023 at 19:59):

Anyway, there's a result of Cortiñas and Weibel in Homology of Azumaya algebra

For a commutative ring RRR, if A is an Azumaya R-algebra, then HHi(A)=0HH_i(A) = 0HHi​(A)=0 for i>0i > 0i>0, and
A/[A,A]≅RA/[A, A] \cong RA/[A,A]≅R.

This is another way of saying HH∙(A)≅HH∙(R)HH_\bullet (A) \cong HH_\bullet(R)HH∙​(A)≅HH∙​(R).

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 21:02):

Nice!

John Baez (Jun 04 2023 at 21:06):

So, we can wonder if there's a slick way to prove this for people who like bicategories of enriched profunctors.

Or, perhaps using the fact that Azumaya algebras are the same as central separable algebras over RRR. My spidey senses tell me that for a separable algebra AAA we should have A/[A,A]≅Z(A)A/[A,A] \cong Z(A)A/[A,A]≅Z(A), so if it's also central we get A/[A,A]≅Z(A)≅RA/[A,A] \cong Z(A) \cong RA/[A,A]≅Z(A)≅R. But I only know for sure that A/[A,A]≅Z(A)A/[A,A] \cong Z(A)A/[A,A]≅Z(A) in the case of separable (or more generally semisimple) algebras over a field.

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:45):

Hello all! Earlier this month @John Baez told me about this discussion and asked me some questions. So here I am! John asked specifically if I can come up with some string diagram proofs of the equivalence between various definitions of Azumaya object. One barrier to doing that is that I had to figure out how the proof goes again! I'm pleasantly surprised my 2014 paper on this [Joh14] is finding some use, but it's been long enough that I'm a little annoyed at how some of it is written.

So, to make myself feel better, I figured out what I think is a better explanation of the key step. I still don't know how to make string diagrams for the proof (and I have some doubts about whether it's possible) but I thought at least I could explain the non-string proof here in case someone else wants to try.

(Warning: I'm about to paste in a bunch of comments; apologies to anyone that I'm inadvertently annoying!)

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:46):

Here's the setup: Suppose M is a symmetric monoidal bicategory with two additional features. (1) a closed structure, and (2) an autonomous structure. Autonomous means that there is an (-)^{op} operation that switches source/target of 1-cells, like taking op of a category or regarding a left A-module as a right A^{op} module. (I don't think this is enough explanation for someone who isn't familiar with this stuff, but I'm going to skip it unless someone would like me to say more.)

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:47):

I'll write the monoidal product of M with a dot, like A.B, just for ease of reading and typing. We'll also need composition of 1-cells, and I'll write that as juxtaposition, like FG = F \circ G. One of the decisions I now find annoying in that 2014 paper is that I used "diagrammatic composition"; I'm not going to do that here. So, in this explanation, FG means first apply G, and then F.

I'll write k for the monoidal unit of M. I'll also pretend that the unit constraints for k are identities. I don't love doing that, but I think I won't type the rest of this if I have to work out the unit stuff carefully. (There will be some other points where I'll have to be a bit glib; apologies in advance.)

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:48):

For an object A of M, I'll say A is invertible as a 0-cell if there exists an object B such that A.B is equivalent (in the bicategorical sense) to k. This means there are 1-cells P: A.B → k and R: k → A.B with PR and RP being isomorphic to the respective identities. (I think some people call this Morita-invertible or something like that, because that's what it means in the classical algebra case. I called it Eilenberg-Watts equivalence in [Joh14].)

I'll denote the unit 1-cell of A as 1 or 1_A. The autonomous structure also lets us regard 1_A as a 1-cell k → A.A^{op}, and I'll write [A] for that. (There is also the other-sided version, which I thankfully won't have to use.)

The central/separable definition of Azumaya algebras is equivalent to [A] being invertible as a 1-cell. That means there is another 1-cell T: A.A^{op} → k such that [A]T and T[A] are isomorphic to the respective identities. I confess I didn't read all of the above discussion carefully, but I think that's the part that people have been figuring out.

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:48):

I know there's a lot more to say about invertibility and adjoint invertibility, and how the presence of a closed structure interacts with that, but I'm skipping it (a) because some of that is discussed above, (b) it's more than I want to write now, and (c) I don't think it's the key step.

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:51):

The Key Step I want to explain here is this: If A is invertible as a 0-cell, then [A] is invertible as a 1-cell. In [Joh14] this is the implication (v) ⇒ (i) for Theorem 1.6, and there are two paragraphs about it on page 14. Here, I want to split the explanation into three lemmas.

All of the lemmas refer to 1-cells in M:

F:k→CG:C→k.F: k \to C \qquad G: C \to k.F:k→CG:C→k.

Only the middle lemma uses the autonomous structure of M, and none of them use the closed structure. (That's needed for connecting to the other ways of defining Azumaya.)

I can add proofs of these lemmas if there is interest. but for now I'll just give the gist of the argument.

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:54):

Lemma 0 (Eckmann-Hilton)
Consider the composite FG:C→k→CFG: C \to k \to CFG:C→k→C. There is an isomorphism

FG≅(1C.G)(F.1C)FG \cong (1_C . G) (F . 1_C)FG≅(1C​.G)(F.1C​)

(Note: this isn't exactly correct as stated, because the right-hand side doesn't have the same source/target as the left hand side; so there are some implicit unit constraints here. But this isomorphism is the main thing.)
A more precise version is Lemma 3.2 in [Joh14].

Proof idea: basically it's pseudofunctoriality of the monoidal product in M.

Lemma 1
Suppose FG≅1CFG \cong 1_CFG≅1C​. Then F.Gop≅[C]F.G^{op} \cong [C]F.Gop≅[C].

Proof idea: This is basically a duality argument that (I think) is standard at least in some circles. It involves tracking the isomorphism in the hypothesis through the equivalence M(C,C)≃M(k.kop,C.Cop)M(C,C) \simeq M(k.k^{op}, C.C^{op})M(C,C)≃M(k.kop,C.Cop).
(Then there is also more unit stuff k.kop≅kk.k^{op} \cong kk.kop≅k, that I am again skipping.)

Lemma 2
If (F,G)(F,G)(F,G) is an invertible pair of 1-cells between kkk and CCC, and if F≅YXF \cong YXF≅YX for some 1-cells

X:k→DY:D→CX: k \to D \qquad Y: D \to CX:k→DY:D→C

Then (X,GY)(X,GY)(X,GY) is an invertible pair of 1-cells between kkk and DDD.

Proof idea: Lemma 2 is the most involved one. The isomorphism GYX≅1kGYX \cong 1_kGYX≅1k​ is just associativity plus GF≅1kGF \cong 1_kGF≅1k​. The isomorphism XGY≅1DXGY \cong 1_DXGY≅1D​ is basically the long chain of isomorphisms displayed on page 14 of [Joh14]. It uses the Eckmann-Hilton lemma plus some psuedofunctoriality of 1D.−1_D . -1D​.−, associativity, more unit stuff, and FG≅1CFG \cong 1_CFG≅1C​. (I got a little stuck on this at first because I thought I needed Eckmann-Hilton twice, but it's just once, at the beginning.)

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:55):

Now the Key Step I mentioned above is easy to explain. I tried to use the notation of [Joh14] where possible, in case that's useful for someone. If A is invertible as a 0-cell, then we have

P:A.B→kR:k→A.BP: A.B \to k \qquad R: k \to A.BP:A.B→kR:k→A.B

with

PR≅1kRP≅1A.B.PR \cong 1_k \qquad RP \cong 1_{A.B}.PR≅1k​RP≅1A.B​.

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:56):

Let Q=R.PopQ = R.P^{op}Q=R.Pop and S=P.RopS = P.R^{op}S=P.Rop. Then by Lemma 1 we have

S=P.Rop≅[A.B]S = P.R^{op} \cong [A.B]S=P.Rop≅[A.B]

Next, observe

[A.B]≅(1A.Aop.[B]) [A]:k→A.Aop→A.Aop.B.Bop.[A.B] \cong (1_{A.A^{op}} . [B])\, [A] : k \to A.A^{op} \to A.A^{op}.B.B^{op}.[A.B]≅(1A.Aop​.[B])[A]:k→A.Aop→A.Aop.B.Bop.

(Again I'm being a little glib, since the target of [A.B] is A.B.(A.B)opA.B.(A.B)^{op}A.B.(A.B)op, so one needs some symmetries here too.)

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:57):

Now use Lemma 2, with X=AX = AX=A and Y=1A.Aop.[B]Y = 1_{A.A^{op}} . [B]Y=1A.Aop​.[B]. The conclusion is that ([A],T)([A],T)([A],T) is an invertible pair, with T=GY=Q (1A.Aop.[B])T = GY = Q \,(1_{A.A^{op}} . [B])T=GY=Q(1A.Aop​.[B]).

Niles Johnson (Jun 19 2023 at 18:59):

That's basically the end of the explanation, but I can add more if someone would like. As I said above, I don't really know how to make string diagrams for these, but it seems like the Lemmas would be the key place to start trying.

Oh, edit to add: Why don't I know how to make string diagrams for these? I'm familiar with some string diagrams where adjacent strings mean composition of 1-cells, and some others where adjacent strings mean monoidal products in a 1-category (which is also composition of 1-cells in the associated 1-object bicategory). But I don't know about diagrams where one can show both composition and a separate monoidal product. Maybe something more in the realm of surface diagrams is needed, or some fancier string diagrams that I don't know about.

Mike Shulman (Jun 20 2023 at 05:57):

Re: compact closed vs autonomous, I think a compact closed (bi)category is always symmetric monoidal, but at least some of the papers by Day, Street, etc. use "autonomous" to mean a non-symmetric monoidal bicategory with both left and right duals.

Mike Shulman (Jun 20 2023 at 06:03):

Re: string diagrams, I know Bartlett has used a syntax for monoidal bicategories where the strings denote the objects and 1-cells as in a monoidal bicategory, and the 2-cells relate different "pages" of these diagrams. But a fully geometric syntax for monoidal bicategories would indeed involve surface diagrams. Street had some attempts in that direction in "Functorial calculus in monoidal bicategories". More recently the folks behind [[homotopy.io]] have a higher-dimensional syntax that can be manipulated and sliced in different directions.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 14:31):

Let me try outlining my alternative argument. It requires a bunch of facts that themselves take work to check, but seem important in their own right (if true :upside_down:).

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 14:58):

I'll assume we're in a compact closed bicategory; this is basically the same as your autonomous symmetric monoidal bicategory, with slight technical differences that are worth noting. A compact closed bicategory is a symmetric monoidal bicategory M where for every object A there exists a dual A*.

But let me explain: in any monoidal bicategory, a dual of an object A is an object B equipped with a unit

i:I→A⊗Bi : I \to A \otimes Bi:I→A⊗B

and counit

e:B⊗A→Ie: B \otimes A \to Ie:B⊗A→I

satisfying the usual zigzag identities up to isomorphism.

(In Definition 4.11 here Mike Stay uses specified isomorphisms, the zigzagurators, which are required to obey some identities called the 'swallowtail coherence laws'. However Nick Gurski has shown (after Definition 2.3 in Biequivalences in tricategories) that these additional laws, which he calls the 'horizontal cusp laws', can be assumed without loss of generality: if the zigzagurators don't obey these laws we can systematically improve them so that they do. So, I will drop these coherence laws and treat the existence of the zigzagurator isomorphisms as a property, rather than incorporating them as part of the structure of a dual object. See Nick's discussion!)

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 15:00):

This concept of compact closed bicategory seems technically different from your concept of autonomous symmetric monoidal bicategory in that I'm taking the existence of a dual for each object as a property, while you seem to be incorporating a specific choice of a dual as part of the structure of an autonomous symmetric monoidal bicategory.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 15:03):

I think the extra flexibility of my approach may help me, but I believe it's "not a big deal" in the following sense:

Conjecture 1. Given two duals (B,iB,eB)(B, i_B, e_B)(B,iB​,eB​) and (C,iC,eC)(C, i_C, e_C)(C,iC​,eC​) of an object AAA in a monoidal bicategory, there is a canonically defined equivalence between these duals, i.e. an equivalence f:B→Cf: B \to Cf:B→C compatible with the units and counits.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 15:05):

Sorry for the vagueness in this statement, but I realize that if I'm not careful I'll wind up writing a paper here. I'd rather just answer questions than fill in tons of details preemptively.

I'm calling this a Conjecture just to cover my ass; it's a bicategorical analogue of a well-known fact for monoidal categories, namely that any two duals of an object are canonically isomorphic. Probably someone has already proved this analogue somewhere. I'd like a reference!

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 15:21):

I'll say an object BBB is an inverse of an object AAA in a symmetric monoidal bicategory B⊗AB \otimes AB⊗A is equivalent to the tensor unit III. Here I'm using symmetry merely to avoid the need to separately say A⊗B≃IA \otimes B \simeq IA⊗B≃I as well.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 15:41):

Next, I'll use this nice result of Nick Gurski, which again is a generalization of a better-known fact for monoidal categories:

Theorem 2. If BBB is an inverse of some object AAA in a symmetric monoidal bicategory, then BBB is a dual of AAA: that is, there exists a unit

i:I→A⊗Bi: I \to A \otimes Bi:I→A⊗B

and counit

e:B⊗A→Ie: B \otimes A \to Ie:B⊗A→I

obeying the zigzag identities up to isomorphism. Moreover eee and iii are equivalences.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 15:48):

The proof of this is Section 3 of Biequivalences in tricategories: since we know I≃A⊗BI \simeq A \otimes BI≃A⊗B and B⊗A≃IB \otimes A \simeq IB⊗A≃I we can pick equivalences and then systematically improve them so that they obey the zigzag identities up to isomorphism.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 15:58):

I hadn't expected these preliminaries to be so long, but if you accept these things I believe it's easy to show

Key Step. An object AAA in a symmetric monoidal bicategory has an inverse iff for some dual A∗A^*A∗ of AAA the unit i:I→A⊗A∗i: I \to A \otimes A^*i:I→A⊗A∗ is an equivalence. In this case A∗A^\astA∗ is an inverse of AAA.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 16:00):

Proof.   ⟹  \implies⟹ Suppose AAA has an inverse BBB. Then by Theorem 2, BBB is a dual of AAA and the unit i:I→A⊗Bi: I \to A \otimes Bi:I→A⊗B is a equivalence.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 16:02):

⟸\Longleftarrow⟸ Suppose for some dual A∗A^\astA∗ of AAA the unit i:I→A⊗A∗i: I \to A \otimes A^\asti:I→A⊗A∗ is an equivalence. Then A∗⊗A≃A⊗A∗≃IA^\ast \otimes A \simeq A \otimes A^\ast \simeq IA∗⊗A≃A⊗A∗≃I so A∗A^\astA∗ is an inverse of AAA. \qquad \qquad :black_large_square:

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 16:03):

I think this proof of the key step is sufficiently satisfying to justify the longwinded methodological preliminaries!

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 16:06):

In the same way we easily get another of @Niles Johnson's nice results:

Nice Result. An object AAA in a symmetric monoidal bicategory has an inverse iff for some dual A∗A^*A∗ of AAA the counit e:A∗⊗A→Ie: A^\ast \otimes A \to Ie:A∗⊗A→I is an equivalence. In this case A∗A^\astA∗ is an inverse of AAA.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 16:13):

This is nice because in our motivating example - the bicategory of algebras, bimodules and bimodule homomorphisms - the unit i:I→A⊗A∗i: I \to A \otimes A^*i:I→A⊗A∗ is an equivalence iff AAA is central and separable, while e:A∗⊗A→Ie: A^\ast \otimes A \to Ie:A∗⊗A→I is an equivalence iff AAA has two other nice properties:

  • Niles Johnson, Azumaya Objects in Triangulated Bicategories.

Niles Johnson (Jun 22 2023 at 18:07):

I used my Lemma 1 to get P.Rop≃[A.B]≃iA.BP.R^{op} \simeq [A.B] \simeq i_{A.B}P.Rop≃[A.B]≃iA.B​, where the equivalences are symmetries that rearrange the AAA, BBB, AopA^{op}Aop, and BopB^{op}Bop. A dual version would give Q=R.Pop≃eA.BQ = R.P^{op} \simeq e_{A.B}Q=R.Pop≃eA.B​. (I'm skipping all the symmetry stuff because, as you said, it starts feeling like one is writing too much!)

Niles Johnson (Jun 22 2023 at 18:08):

At some point earlier you asked about a specific formula for the inverse TTT of [A]=iA[A] = i_A[A]=iA​. Here's what I think it is in both notations, where I'm writing Ae=A.AopA^e = A.A^{op}Ae=A.Aop and β\betaβ denotes a symmetry equivalence.

Ae→1Ae.[B]Ae.Be→βA.B.Aop.Bop→P.RopkA^e \xrightarrow{1_{A^e}.[B]} A^e.B^e \xrightarrow{\beta} A.B.A^{op}.B^{op} \xrightarrow{P.R^{op}} kAe1Ae​.[B]​Ae.Beβ​A.B.Aop.BopP.Rop​k

or (with a different symmetry β\betaβ)

Ae→1Ae.iBAe.Be→β(A.B)op.A.B.→eA.BkA^e \xrightarrow{1_{A^e}.i_B} A^e.B^e \xrightarrow{\beta} (A.B)^{op}.A.B. \xrightarrow{e_{A.B}} kAe1Ae​.iB​​Ae.Beβ​(A.B)op.A.B.eA.B​​k

So, in this formula, the inverse TTT is basically made from iBi_BiB​ and eA.Be_{A.B}eA.B​.

Niles Johnson (Jun 22 2023 at 18:09):

From this point of view, I guess the Key Step seems to be saying that (iA.B,eA.B)(i_{A.B},e_{A.B})(iA.B​,eA.B​) is a pair of inverse equivalences if and only if both (iA,eA)(i_A,e_A)(iA​,eA​) and (iB,eB)(i_B,e_B)(iB​,eB​) are such. Is that really right?! It seems a bit surprising, but I guess the point is that (waving hands and squinting) we have things like iA.B≅(iA).(iB)≅((1.iB)∘iA)i_{A.B} \cong (i_A).(i_B) \cong ((1.i_B)\circ i_A)iA.B​≅(iA​).(iB​)≅((1.iB​)∘iA​), and similarly for eee.

John Baez (Jun 22 2023 at 21:43):

Yes, I sort of like your use of kkk to mean the unit object and AopA^{\text{op}}Aop to mean the dual of an object. When I first saw that I thought it was a clever trick to get a paper on symmetric monoidal bicategories published in a traditional algebra journal. :upside_down: But it's true, there are two levels of dual here so maybe it's confusing to use ∗\ast∗ for both. Back when I writing a lot about nnn-categories with duals I decided it was hopeless to make up a new kind of star for each level of duality. But with just two maybe I should do this.

Mike Shulman (Jul 03 2023 at 05:26):

I don't know if this is relevant, but there's a new paper on the arXiv by Coquand, Lombardi, and Neuwirth called Constructive Remarks on Azumaya Algebra. The abstract says:

We study etale topology and the notion of Azumaya algebra over a commutative ring constructively. As an application of the syntactic version of Barr's Theorem, we show the equivalence between two definitions of Azumaya algebra.
